title: Is it true there is a $100 charge for each individual credit card account being owed to in a chapter 7 bankruptcy?
question: Hello, I went to a free consultation with an attorney today for a chapter 7 bankruptcy and when going over the charges, they mentioned that aside from the attorney fees, credit report, and court filing fees, there was a $100 charge for each individual credit card account to which I carried a balance. Is this accurate, and if so, is it a fixed rate or depends on individual attorney? Thank you!
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Bankruptcy court,Debt,Secured debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Real estate and bankruptcy,Real estate,Social security,Fees
answers:
Wait. An additional $100.00 extra per each creditor? Sounds absurd, however, chapter 7 bankruptcy fees are freely negotiated between attorney and client. Some law firms may entice you to choose their services and try to get you in their door based on pricing alone, such as when offering bottom dollar chapter 7 bankruptcy services for $595 or $795. I would advise you to use extreme caution here.

Bankruptcy lawyers provide a valuable service to their clients, oftentimes for 4 months or longer from case preparation through discharge and case completion. It should be no surprise that this work comes at a price.

Clearly your senses were right to wonder about this fee scheme and if the per-creditor charge is standard among bankruptcy law firms. Don't be lured in by flashing lights and lowest prices --- you may get exactly what you pay for.

Best of luck

Filing fee for C7 BK is flat fee. There is no extra filing fee based on number of credit cards.
Attorney fees are negotiable. Your attorney may charge attorney fees based on number of creditors.

Most attorneys charge a flat fee for a basic chapter 7 bankruptcy. If you have more than 50 creditors, if you need reaffirmation agreements or other motions/adversaries in your bankruptcy then the fees might/would increase. Before you decide to have this attorney represent you, I urge you to check the California State Bar Website to make sure the attorney doesn't have any record of discipline, which would also verify the person you met with is a licensed attorney in California.
That said, the US Trustee's Office reviews attorney fees in Chapter 7 cases, they are disclosed in the Petition Documents, if the fees are not reasonable for the services provided the US Trustee's Office will file a motion to force the attorney to return the amount of the fees above reasonable.
You may want to consult with a Certified Specialist in Bankruptcy Law, the odds are higher you will receive competent counsel and reasonable attorney fees.

The Bankruptcy court does not charge based on the number of accounts you have. There is a flat filing fee. Furthermore, Bankruptcy under chapter 7 is a federal law, so the state you are in shouldn't matter or change the fees. It is good advice, like the others have given, that you consult with another attorney.

There are some attorneys out there who quote a very low fee to get you in the door and then do things like what happened to you. Every attorney is free to charge whatever he or she wants in what ever fashion (subject to some degree of oversight from the bankruptcy court). If I were you, I would talk to a couple of other attorneys until you find one in whom you feel confident and who's fee seems reasonable.

Legals are negotiated between the attorney and client. I personally based my fees on the complexity of the case. I once had a client a field business...almost 400 creditors and more than $2 million in debtor. That client paid a LOT more than the widow on social security with 4 or 5 credit cards that I once helped. The only person charging $100 per card would be the attorney. Get a second opinion on your case.

The filing fee is the same for all people who file the same type of case. Perhaps the attorney charges fees based on the number of accounts the client has? That is VERY unusual, though most attorneys do charge additional fees for bankruptcy clients who own real estate, or have secured debts such as auto loans,

I recommend that you to contact a couple other attorneys in your area, and ask them this question.
You may want to talk to another attorney. I wish you much success.

I can't speak for California but I can speak for the federal bankruptcy code, which is there is no charge by the bankruptcy Cou rt per amount of credit cards. The filing fee is the same across the country, $335, whether you have three credit cards or 100
